Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Inquiry into the meaning and justification of fundamental ideas and beliefs concerning reality, knowledge, and values; application to relevant topics in ethics, religion, and politics.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Same as PHI 2010 with honorslevel content.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: A study of reasoning in philosophy: the role of inconsistency, infinite regress arguments, modeling, and system building, discovery procedures, diagonalization, and contract and paradigm case arguments.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: A study of sentence and predicate logics, with introduction to modal, epistemic, deontic, multi-valued, and indeterminant logics.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: The logic of conversation, informal fallacies, and reasoning about human action.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Research in logic applied to ethics, especially for science and technology. Uses of simulation and modeling to study philosophical problems in ethics.

PHI3033 - Philosophy, Religion, and the.name: PHI3033 - Philosophy, Religion, and the Environment

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: A multicultural treatment of the influence of philosophical and religious views on our understanding of, and relation to, the environment.

Prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
Prerequisites.text: Philosophy or Humanities major or C.I.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Sources, methods, and styles of research in Philosophy. Aimed at enhancing the research, reading, and writing skills of undergraduate philosophy students.

Prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
Prerequisites.text:
Complete the following: 
PHI2101 - Formal Logic I (3)

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Systematic study of propositional and first-order predicate logic; logistic systems and axiomatic methods; problems of metatheory, including consistency, completeness, and decidability.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Recent and contemporary attempts to understand the relation of mind to body, the relation of consciousness to personhood, and the relation of psychology to neurobiology.

PHI3323 - Minds and Machines: Philosophy.name: PHI3323 - Minds and Machines: Philosophy of Cognitive Science

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Assumptions undergirding research in Cognitive Science.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Philosophical assumptions and foundations of major psychological movements plus other philosophically interesting issues.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Ethics of virtual worlds as contrasted to the physical world, the use of simulation, virtual environments, and modeling in philosophy, especially in ethics.

PHI3626 - Advanced Ethics in Science and.name: PHI3626 - Advanced Ethics in Science and Technology

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Critical thinking applied to ethics in science and technology.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Applied ethics examining legal, religious and other cultural prescriptions related to sexuality, marriage, reproduction, child-rearing and other forms of familial relationship and caregiving.

PHI3638 - Ethical Issues in the 21st Cen.name: PHI3638 - Ethical Issues in the 21st Century

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Applications of ethical theory and moral problem-solving to contemporary issues.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Major contemporary views in environmental ethics, including individual and holistic approaches, deep ecology, ecofeminism, and social ecology

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Major classical & contemporary topics in ethics, including value theory, utilitarian, deontological, virtue-based & feminist approaches to ethics, rights, & justice; some examination of metaethical issues.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Key issues and debates in the area of animal ethics, including both theoretical and applied dimensions.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Philosophies of life and the notion of "the good life."

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: An examination of basic ideas, beliefs, attitudes, and functions of religion, with emphasis upon questions of conceptual meaning and cognitive justification.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Emergence of two discrete ways of knowing: Faith and Reason.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: The traditional problem of evil encompassing philosophical, theological, logical, and natural interpretations and assessments of moral and natural evil.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Traditional and contemporary African philosophical thought with primary emphasis on post-colonial philosophy in sub-Saharan Africa.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: An investigation into the nature of human artistic experience, with special reference to questions of form, perception, and style.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Nature of language and the relationships between language, reality, cognition, and culture.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Classical and contemporary theories of knowledge. A critical examination of various forms of, and reasons for, skepticism, criteria for truth and justification for belief.

Prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
Prerequisites.text: Junior standing and either PHI 2010, PHI 2011, PHI 2108, or C.I.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Different ways of understanding relations between mind, body, and nature. Self-knowledge as articulated by western and non-western philosophies from ancient to contemporary times.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Philosophic study of approaches to knowledge, with emphasis on contributions of the knower to how things are known.

Prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
Prerequisites.text: Junior standing or PHI 2010 or C.I.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: An examination of the conceptual foundations and methodology of modern science.

Prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
Prerequisites.text: Junior standing or PHI 2010 or C.I.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: An examination of the objectives, methods and guiding norms of the social sciences and their role in the development of human knowledge.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Topics include appearance and reality, actions and events, necessity and possibility, identity, nature of persons, mindbody dualism, causality, and free will and determinism.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: An application of contemporary thinking to ethical issues arising from the biological sciences, including human and animal experimentation, genetic engineering, biodiversity.

PHI4633H - Honors Ethics and Biological.name: PHI4633H - Honors Ethics and Biological Science

Prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
Prerequisites.text: BSC 2010C, a course in Philosophy, and consent of Honors.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Contemporary thinking on ethical issues arising from the biological sciences, including human and animal experiments, genetic engineering, and biodiversity.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Ethics of clinical medicine and medical research.

Prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
Prerequisites.text: Junior standing and PHI 2010, or C.I.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Ethical issues associated with the mind sciences, especially neuroscience.

PHI4690 - Ethics in Nanoscience and Nano.name: PHI4690 - Ethics in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology

Prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
Prerequisites.text: Completion of GEP or Junior standing.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Ethical implications of rapid developments in nanoscience and nanotechnology.

Prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
Prerequisites.text:
Complete the following: 
PHI2010 - Introduction to Philosophy (3)

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Changing course content. A specific topic being covered by the media will be selected for philosophical examination. Course is web enhanced.

PHI4935 - Topics in Philosophy of Mind.name: PHI4935 - Topics in Philosophy of Mind

Prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
Prerequisites.text: PHI 3320, PHI 3451 or PHI 3323 or C.I.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Recent debate in philosophy of mind. Variable topics. Examples: mental representation, consciousness, concepts, free will.

Prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
Prerequisites.text: Senior standing and Philosophy major, or C.I.

Course Description.title: Course Description
Course Description.text: Capstone course on research, developing effective oral and written communication skills.
